questions.text: A schizophrenic patient is laughing in the funeral of his bother. He keeps on smiling and appreciating the priest and all the relatives over there. His behavior can be considered as;

A 23-year-old college student comes to the physician because her roommates are worried about her eating. She tells the physician that she regularly eats large amounts of food (more than 10,000 calories on occasion) and then has to 'punish herself' and 'get rid of it'. She explains that she does this by sticking her finger down her throat, which causes her to vomit. She tried to hide this activity from her roommates, but on more than one occasion they have heard her retching in the bathroom. The patient is 5'5'' tall and BMI is 25.5. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This college student has the classic symptoms of bulimia, in which she eats huge amounts of food (binging) and then feels the need to "get rid of it" (purging)
  • Her body mass index (BMI) is within a normal range, and therefore anorexia is ruled out

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 10-year history of episodes in which she eats large quantities of food, such as eight hamburgers and three quarts of ice cream, at a single sitting. Because of her intense feelings of guilt, she then repeatedly induces vomiting. This cycle repeats itself several times a week. She is extremely ashamed of her behaviour but says, "I can't stop doing it". On examination, which of the following physical findings is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis for this woman is BULIMIA NERVOSA
  • Physical findings can include:
    • Dental caries
    • Round face caused by enlarged parotid glands
    • Calluses on the fingersresulting from recurrent self-induced vomiting
  • Lanugo and muscle wasting result from the severe weight loss characteristic of anorexia nervosa (OPTION B & C)

questions.text: To Check the higher mental function of the patient, examiner says some numbers and patient is asked to repeat them. The examiner starts with a single number and gradually increases to two number sequence, three number sequence and so on and so forth, till patient fails to repeat. This test can be applied for all except:

On asking the name of the city that he lives in, an elderly patient having right hemispheric stroke replied, 'Jodhpur'. Next, on asking him the current year, he replied the same answer 'Jodhpur'. In fact, on asking any further question, he kept on giving the same reply. Such a stream of thought disorder is known as;
questions.solution: • Perseveration is a stream thought disorder in which there is repetition of a particular response, such as a word, phrase, or gesture, despite the absence or cessation of a stimulus, usually caused by brain injury or other organic disorder rather than a psychopathology

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the psychiatric out-patient-clinic with increased rate, tone and volume of speech. On asking anything, he would reply with unnecessary and insignificant information with elaborate detailing. Such over-inclusion of extraneous information would make it difficult to follow his train of thought or arrive at a meaningful answer. Such a speech pattern can be present in all of the conditions, except:
questions.solution:
• The characteristic pattern of formal thought disorder described in this case is called circumstantiality.
  • Circumstantiality occurs when thinking proceeds slowly with many unnecessary and trivial details, but finally the point is reached
  • The goal of thinking is never completely lost and thinking proceeds towards it by an intricate and convoluted path
  • It is seen typically in manic episodes of bipolar mood disorder and schizo affective disorder, in personality traits associated with temporal lobe epilepsy (GestautGeschwind Syndrome), in obsessive personality traits.
  • It is uncommon in Schizotypal personality disorder which is characterized by social withdrawnness, isolation and decreased social interaction, magical thinking.

questions.text: A 20 year old man is asked about his college name and he replies that education is all about discipline, students and teachers. He can be classified as having a disorder of;
questions.solution:
• It is tangentiality: Answering in a distant related manner.

Disturbances of Thought:

  1. Flow/Stream of thought
  2. Form of thought
  3. Content of thought
  4. Possession of thought

questions.text: Common features seen in schizophrenia and depression are all except;
questions.solution: • Formal thought disorders are seen only in schizophrenia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male hypomanic patient was brought by his family members for the first time to the clinic. His attitude was over-friendly, jolly and talkative. On asking him about his mood, he replied, 'I feel like I'm on the top of the world, the happiest person on earth!' and started singing a movie song without provocation. On asking him the reason for his happiness, he or his family members could not state any specific reason. In this case, the mood of the patient can be termed as;
questions.solution:
• Euphoric moodis described as exaggerated feeling of well-being that is inappropriate to real events and without any obvious specific reason
  • Can occur with drug intoxication such as opiates, amphetamines, and alcohol and in manic episodes

choices.text: Can follow simple verbal commands and handle money

questions.text: A child with IQ 50, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• 50 - 69: Mild MR
  • Mild MR people can have an independent living, handle money, study till 6th class

questions.text: Risk of which disorder is high in adolescent, if ADHD case is left untreated during childhood?
An adolescent boy requiring 24-hour care, and pervasive support for every aspect of daily routines has IQ of 19. Which is the severity level of intellectual disability in this case?
questions.solution:
• Profound intellectual disability constitutes approximately 1 to 2 percent of individuals with intellectual disability.
  • Most individuals with profound intellectual disability have identifiable causes for their condition.

questions.text: DSM-5 includes all of the following specifiers in specific learning disorder except:
questions.solution:
• DSM-5 specifiers in specific learning disorder:
    • With impairment in reading
    • With impairment in written expression
    • With impairment in mathematics

questions.text: After CABG, a 50 year old man is shifted to ICU. After 2 days of admission in ICU, he appears to be agitated, disoriented, facing sleeping problem. He speaks to someone in ICU in the absence of others. He asks his wife to keep eyes at the main door as someone can enter there and harm him. Family members are reporting that suddenly he started having these symptoms. Which of the following does not suggest that he is suffering from schizophrenia?

A 60 year old man has fluctuating levels of attention and alertness, recurrent visual hallucinations and Parkinson's features. Many a times he claims that his wife is not the real one as she is replaced by a similar looking lady. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Capgrass - Lewy body dementia

DEMENTIA:

Delusion of Misidentification:

  • Capgrass syndrome: It is also known as "DELUSION OF DOUBLE". Known person is believed to a stranger. Patient believes that a familiar person is replaced by an imposter
  • Fregoli syndrome: A stranger appears to be a known person. Patient believes that a familiar person can change his physical appearance and disguise as a stranger.

Capgrass Syndrome

Fregoli Syndrome

questions.text: A 21-year-old lady presented with history of episodes where she would behave as if possessed by some spirit. She would display extraordinary strength and become aggressive towards her family members, speak in foreign language and display bizarre behavior. She would always claim amnesia for the event. Pick the correct diagnosis for her condition.
questions.solution:
• Possession trance, involves single or episodic alternations in the state of consciousness, characterized by the exchange of the person's customary identity with a new identity usually attributed to a spirit, divine power, deity, or another person.
  • In this possessed state, the individual exhibits stereotypical and culturally determined behaviors or experiences being controlled by the possessing entity.
  • There must be partial or full amnesia of the event.

questions.text: A female patient of bipolar disorder is on lithium for last 1 year. Which of the following side effects is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
• Tardive dyskinesia is an EPS, side effect of antipsychotic drug.
  • Remaining all others are the S/Es of Lithium

questions.text: A 38 year old female, presents to OPD with complaints of persistent sadness, sleeping problems, loss of interest in activities and poor appetite for past few months. As per her condition, she is diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which drug is the most appropriate for initial treatment?
questions.solution: • SSRI is the first line management for depression

questions.text: Procedure in shown image is used for which of the following psychiatric conditions?
questions.solution: • Its rTMS (repetitive Transcranial Magnetic stimulation), used for treatment of major depression.

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady with many previous hospitalizations is brought by police to casualty. She is wearing full make-up, green lipstick, shiny green nail polish, and green jewellery. She asks everyone at the admission unit to call her Ms. Green. She speaks a lot. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
• Exuberant dressing and makeup suggests elevated mood.
  • It is possible that the lady described in this scenario has bipolar illness.

choices.text: Major depressive episode with post-partum onset

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is referred for assessment by the obstetric team. She is reported to be feeling depressed following the birth of her first baby three days ago. She has no history of depressive disorder. The baby is healthy, although the woman required a caesarean delivery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Baby blues typically occur 3-6 days following the birth of the baby in 50-60% of mothers.

choices.text: Their symptoms are alloplastic that is, they adapt by trying to alter the external environment rather than themselves
Onset is usually seen in adolescence or early adulthood
They easily seek treatment for their symptoms and are eager to surrender their characteristic behaviour patterns

questions.text: Persons with personality disorders have all these characteristics except:
questions.solution:
• PDs are ego syntonic. Patients don't want treatment.
    • Persons with personality disorders are far more likely to refuse psychiatric help and to deny their problems than persons with anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, or obsessive-compulsive disorder

choices.text: Lack of close friends and confidantes

questions.text: Schizotypal Personality Disorder can be differentiated from Schizoid Personality Disorder by which of the following behaviour patterns?
questions.solution:
• Both Schizoid and Schizotypal personality disorder have social withdrawal and reduced capacity for close relationships, remain isolated and alone, are emotionally indifferent and cold
  • However, Schizotypal personality disorder is marked by eccentricities of behaviour such as
    • Ideas of reference
  • Odd beliefs or magical thinking

questions.text: A 45 year old man with unacceptable sexual desires becomes a painter and starts making nude paintings. Here, the sexual desires are getting an outlet and its socially acceptable since painting nudes is considered an art. Which type of defense mechanism it can be considered as;

choices.text: In coherence and flight of ideas

questions.text: A patient with paranoid schizophrenia talks about "cyana-pi" but he is not able to explain it and reach a conclusion. He often uses old words in a different fashion, like "Time vessel for wrist watch". His condition can be referred as;
questions.solution:
• Cyan-pi ( coining of a new word - neologism)
  • Metonyms: Using old word in a different manner/word approximation)

choices.text: Patient A: My wife is cheating on me
Patient B: I am the most powerful person in the world
Patient C: Neighbors are talking about me
Patient D: My brain is controlled by a microchip

questions.text: Four patients are talking about the content of their thoughts. Which of the following is considered as a bizarre delusion?
questions.solution:
• Bizarre delusion: scientifically impossible and culturally implausible
  • Nonbizarre delusion: False, but possible

questions.text: Which of the following is a wrong match?

A 22 year old, suffering from chronic schizophrenia is put on 1st generation antipsychotic drug (haloperidol 20mg/day). After 5 days of starting the drug, the patient shows restlessness, fidgetiness, irritability and can't sit at one place. Which of the following is the most appropriate line of management for this patient?
questions.solution: • Symptoms are relevant with akathisia (EPS). DOC is propranolol

questions.text: Identify the type of schizophrenia;
questions.solution:
• SCZ + Mental retardation: Pfropf
  • SCZ SCZ + self-mutilation: Van Gogh syndrome
  • SCZ + disorientation: Oneirodid SCZ

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her husband after she begins screaming that her children are calling to her and becomes hysterical. The husband states that 2 weeks previously, the couple's two children were killed in a car accident, and since that time the has been agitated, disorganized, and incoherent. He states that she will not eat because she believes he has been poisoning her food, and she has not slept for the past 2 days. The patient believes that the nurses in the emergency room are going to cause her harm as well. The patient is sedated and later sent home. One week later, all her symptoms remit spontaneously. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Characterized by the sudden appearance of delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized speech or behaviour, usually following a severe stressor
  • The episode lasts at least 1 day and less than 1 month and is followed by full spontaneous remission

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the physician after complaining about a visual hallucination of a transparent phantom of his own body. Which of the following specific syndromes is this patient most likely to be displaying?
questions.solution:
• Autoscopic psychosishas as its main symptom the visual hallucination of a transparent phantom of one’s own body
  • Capgras syndrome (delusion of doubles) is a fixed belief that familiar persons have been replaced by identical imposters who behave exactly like the original person (OPTION A)
  • Lycanthropyis the delusion that the person is a werewolf or other animal(OPTION B)
  • Cotard syndromeis the false perception of having lost everything, including money, status, strength, health, and internal organs (OPTION C)

questions.text:
A 24 year old male comes to your clinic with complains of frequent checking of doors even when they are locked. He is distressed about this fact. Consider the following statements regarding his case;
1. His condition is considered as ego dystonic
2. SSRI is very useful
3. Risperidone may be used in SSRI resistant cases to augment the response
4. Systemic desensitization is the best behavior therapy Which of the above are correct statements?

A 28-year-old woman is brought to see a psychiatrist by her mother. The patient insists that nothing is wrong with her, but the mother notes that the patient has been slowly but progressively isolating herself from everyone. She now rarely leaves the house. The mother says she can hear the patient talking to "people who aren't there" while she's in her room. On examination, the patient is noted to have auditory hallucinations and the delusional belief that her mother is going to kick her out of the house so that it can be turned into a theme park.
Which of the following is the lifetime prevalence for this disorder?
questions.solution:
• Schizophrenia affects 1% of the adult population
  • The incidence is comparable in all societies
  • The 1-year incidence rate is 0.2 per 1000

choices.text: There can be loss of bladder and bowel control

questions.text: A girl child is presented with stereotyped behaviour, hand wringing and deceleration in head growth as per age. Which of the following is wrong about her condition?

choices.text: Suggest him to leave the job

questions.text: If a high profile person wants to leave the alcohol but he is asking that he can't use disulfiram drug. He has to attend high profile meetings with his clients and he has to take alcohol professionally sometimes. What should be prescribed next?
questions.solution:
• Disulfiram is not given to all patients due to severe reaction.
  • Anticraving agents:
    • Naltrexone
    • Acamprosate
    • Topiramate
    • Gabapentine
    • Ondensatron
    • Fluoxetine, and Baclofen.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department. She is unresponsive to questions, stumbles around the room, and is agitated. On physical examination, you notice that she smells of alcohol, and she is not cooperative during the remainder of the examination. Administration of what medicine would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
• The most appropriate treatment is the immediate administration of thiamine
  • This patient presents with Wernicke encephalopathy,characterized by the triad of delirium, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia
  • Thiamine must be given prior to glucose in patients suspected of having this disorder

questions.text: Match the following paraphilias;

A 50-year-old homeless male veteran is brought to the emergency department by the police for disruptive behaviour. On mental status examination, he has an elevated affect, but also has psychomotor agitation and paranoia; he says he "feels fantastic" but is wary of answering any questions, quickly becoming irritated. On physical examination, the patient exhibits a moderately elevated blood pressure and pulse rate. He is most likely intoxicated with which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
• Cocaine (or other stimulants such as amphetamine) intoxication can present with -
    • Euphoria
    • Irritability
    • Anxiety
    • Psychotic symptoms such as paranoia
    • Elevated vital signs
  • Conversely, intoxication with alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, and opiates generally causes depression, somnolence, and depressed vital signs (OPTIONS B,C & D)

questions.text: After binge-consuming a couple of drinks (containing alcohol) at a party, a man decides to return his home by driving his car alone, after 1-2 hours of taking the last drink as he feels less intoxicated and confident to drive. This describes;
questions.solution: • Mellanby effect: Increasing dose of a substance has more behavioral changes than falling level.

questions.text: Match the following;
questions.solution:
1. Premature ejaculation: Disorder of orgasm phase. Treatment - Squeeze technique and Stop-start technique (semans technique) – SSRI drugs
  2. Erectile Dysfunction: Disorder of excitement phase. Treatment - PDE-5 inhibitors like Sildenafil, Tadalafil and Verdenafil.
  3. Injectable drug: Alprostidil (to be injected in urethra or corpora cavernosa)

choices.text: He is a case of factitious illness

questions.text: A 21 year old guy is admitted in hospital with on and off headache. Sometimes he appears to be disoriented. His MRI was done which was not so significant. His EEG was taken around 8pm when he was speaking nicely with everyone. Delta waves were seen on his EEG. Which of the following is true about his condition?
questions.solution: • This is a case of somnambulism

questions.text: Mr Mohan, a 45 year old male, is a known case of major depression. He has been taking anti-depressants for last 2 years. He is brought to emergency with complaints of palpitations, blurred vision, difficulty in passing urine. His ECG shows prolonged PR interval. Family members are reporting that he has consumed multiple pills. Which antidepressant can cause his symptoms?

A patient suffering from contamination phobia was asked by therapist to follow behind him and touch everything he touches. During process therapist kept talking quietly and calmly to the patients. The patient was asked to repeat the procedure twice daily. The procedure is called as;

choices.text: It causes release of chemical from locus coeruleus that causes awakening
It has histaminic action in brain that leads to awakening
It inhibits adenosine receptors, leading to awakening

questions.text: A patient is complaining of difficulty falling asleep. He takes black coffee everyday and usually one hour before the bed. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness?
questions.solution:
• Accumulation of adenosine in basal forebrain area causes lethargy, drowsiness and fatigue.
  • Caffeine inhibits adenosine receptors and increases wakefulness.

choices.text: Start the treatment as a case of heart attack
Consider her as a case of panic disorder and start SSRI

questions.text: A 23 year old female is brought to emergency with complaints of pain in chest, palpitations, shortness of breath and sweating. She appears to be very frightened and saying that she could die as she can feel her heart beats. What should be the line of management?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis: Panic disorder
  • 1st priority is to rule out heart attack

questions.text: A 19 year old girl feels very confident whenever she wears shirt, pant and boot of her brother. Otherwise she doesn't have any concern for sexual surgery and sexual gratification. What is the correct term to describe her condition?
Match the following;

choices.text: Chew and park method is applied
Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
Intravenous route of nicotine is not preferred

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding nicotine substitution therapy?
A 12 year old girl cleans her room multiple times to avoid scolding by her mother. This is called as;
questions.solution: COGNITIVE STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT
